now ask anyone with real experience in photography.


If you have a scene that is 30deg wide and you shoot it at a given resolution x in pixels/inch from a distance of Z with a lens of focal-length Fz, what happens if you shoot it from a distance of Z/2 with a lens with the same effective FOV? Now you run into a different problem entirely, which is the effect of shooting a wider real FOV through the 2nd lens, which is likely to have a significant reduction in linear resolution compared to the first lens used. Even if the camera used is the same and distortion effects from vibration, thermal and refraction-index variations are neglected. To actually see the benefits of shooting the scene at higher resolution, you need to optimize the CAMERA SYSTEM before you begin to worry about optimizing the processing electronics.


Now you've likely just dramatically scaled-up the cost of the camera equipment.
Before you even begin to talk about the processing equipment.
Otherwise you don't have image-data that is worth recording & processing at 4k.


Now you have to talk about lossless recording & processing.


Then you are very likely to run back to 1080p H-265 and forget that you ever heard of 4k.

I honestly am not really surprised that you're just finding this out. Even in 2018.
Because you made this video. When, very simply, you could easily have just asked yourself a simple question:


What do I qualitatively gain from shooting & rendering in 4k instead of 1080p or even 720p?
Not to mention 4k-60 vs 720p-30?


Apparently this question either never occurred to you or was insufficiently interesting to you.


Here's my simple response. I realize that this will be rebuffed for predictable reasons but still.
The difference in resolution between 4k and 1080p is imperceptible to the human eye unless and until you get so close to the display medium that it IS perceptible. But a) now you can only see a small fraction of the entire image B) even so the files are 8x the size even with the latest & greatest compression (H.265) and it is simply so much easier and faster to shoot & render in 1080p or 720p than 4k that 2 attempts were enough to dissuade ME. Obviously not you but still.


Basically as a mathematician and an engineer, the real issue is why do something in a way that is very difficult and takes a lot of time & effort when you can easily figure-out how to accomplish the same goal, or very near to it, with a lot less time & effort...not to mention cost? Choosing between 4k and any of a number of lower resolutions really does not require a Mensa certificate. Now of course if you're talking about 8k, that's entirely different ;)


The rest of it, if you'd ever done any real work in the field of parallel and distributed processing, you'd know that very well. And you don't need a computer for that either. It's pretty damm hard (not quite impossible but still difficult) to write two letters by hand at the same time. Can it be done? Of course. Is it a wise use of time, effort and resources to do so? Probably not until the required production becomes very large. Need more examples?

Premiere has historically been slow to render and especially encode to H264. The 2018 12.1 version was improved to use Intel's Quick Sync hardware acceleration for encoding (not playback), however to my knowledge the i9-7980XE CPU on your Puget Systems machine doesn't have Quick Sync. There is a 3rd-party NVENC plugin which supposedly enables Premiere to use similar nVidia hardware encoding acceleration. I think the 8-core i9-9900KE is the highest-core-count CPU that currently has Quick Sync hardware. You could try taking a small test timeline, installing the free version of DaVinci Resolve, doing a render/export test, and comparing it to Premiere. This could help determine if the bottleneck is hardware or software. Although your new Puget Systems machine yielded a major improvement there might be further improvement possible for the encode phase if hardware accelerated.

I am really not convinced by what pugets promises. Yeah obviously there are some constraints and caveats about what model should be used for your task. The cheaper your build the more important it gets. However especially for higher prices builds there are just very few rules which are important for choosing correct hardware for your use. And if you invest the extra (you pay puget) into the hardware probably it will be faster for any normal task (video editing and rendering included). And unlike stated in the video, yes if you go higher priced you get a better performance.



The reason for that is very simple, all common PC hardware is just still multipurpose hardware. And yes there is a trend to have hardware acceleration for some tasks, like e.g. video decoding. However you will find video decoding in just about any GPU. Everything else like video editing or rendering is either dependent on the CPU or at most the GPU, but even the GPU is more or less a multi purpose device (especially used for non live rendering). The are different reasons for why there is not more hardware acceleration around: One is that many algorithms e.g. for encoding are very complicated, so are much harder to be implemented in hardware than in software. Also there are constant updates, tweaks and changes for e.g. rendering engines. Which are too complicated to be implemented in hardware, alone the amount of configuration which is available makes it ridiculously hard and huge if implemented as a transistor logic. Many effects in video editing don't even use SIMD, AVX or GPU because even thoose little paralleliztation make it much harder to implement if it is at all possible. There is support for H.265 video encoding by nvidia GPUs and intel CPUs but both hardware implementations in the highest settings are significantly worse than even similarly long running Software Encoding, because the software could be tweaked over time, and some things are just too complicately to implement in hardware.


This was a short information about hardware acceleration, but back to the main topic. There have been just two rules (since AMD Zen 2) for buying high end hardware related to your task:
1. For any highend task buy AMD Zen 2, the higher number the better performance. (Except maybe some scientific stuff, with AVX ...)
2. Buy NVidia and not AMD


And for everything else just look for the highest number in the data sheet and you got the best PC. Are there some more factors which could be important? Yes there are, there can be some considerations be made about whether to buy one or more GPUs and wheter to buy Quadro of GeForce. But for the extra Puget charges you probably can buy one or two extra Geforce GPUs anyway. So I am pretty sure that for at least non scientific work loads the extra Puget charges and does is not worth it. And any other more basic considerations for high end workstations should be doable by any builder of high end machines.

So I don't have anything against their buisness model, however I really dislike their claim/marketing that the hardware selection is that important and the amount of detail put into it is really not neccessary.

So I edit video for living. mostly commercial content. I have found certain types of media takes longer to render than others. Now I mainly edit HD, but have found when I transcode to to ProRes I get a quality improvement and faster performance while editing. However, transcoding does take time on the front end. You may want to experiment with different file types to see what works best. H.264 Mp4 files always seem to take longer to render out. But you might save some time rendering out from ProRes source files. For certain cameras that shoot natively in wide color/exposure gamut, I will edit as-is. As I don't want to diminish any flexibility on color grading while editing.

Srsly, u should look at ur software and pipeline before throwing hardware on the problem. As everybody knows videos can be cut without re-encoding and the few scenes with overlays that might need re-encoding can be rendered separately and joined.

the reason more cores is not necessarily the answer (apart from the different clock speeds on the two chips) is that the next performance bottle neck involves the data throughput, and whether you can actually make use of all of the cores. If you are stuck on disk transfer rate, some of the cores are idle, if the software cant parallel-ize what its doing properly, some will be idle, and if there is some other shared resource that the cores are all competing for, it wont run at full capacity. Rendering involves reading from disk, decompressing, blending/compositing, interpolating, recompressing and then writing back out to disk - which requires a ton of data to be moved around. Each time you solve one bottleneck you will expose the next one. Their approach to benchmarking is the way to go, especially for mostly single use machines. They are basically "tuning" your computer for the intended use. Software engineers do the same with intended use patterns for common use scenarios. Writing software in such a way as to make maximum use of available resources is a non-trivial programming task.  Thanks for the videos, I love the channel.

There's much that goes into computing performance besides simply core count and clock frequency, but most people don't know better, especially those 9-year-old-minded edgelord PC "gamerz$$$".

In case some enthusiasts & whatnot are interested, one thing worth knowing about is processor cache. The more levels & the bigger each, the better. The lower the level, the faster. Think of them like RAM, but multitudes faster:
Level 1 (L1) Processor Cache, fastest
Level 2 (L2) Processor Cache
Level 3 (L3) Processor Cache
Level 3 (L4) Processor Cache, slowest (but still faster than anything RAM can provide).
As processor technology evolves, more levels may be introduced, and with more memory per level.

The more you look, the more you can learn what is relevant. The cooler the processor, the lesser a problem thermal throttling will be. A CPU also does multiple kinds of operations, and some processors are faster (better) than others for certain operations sometimes even at a lower clock speed. (I.e integer calculation.)

A true BEAST of a PC requires an equally-beasty amount of knowledge. The more you can learn, the better. The processor is also obviously far from being all that matters. And despite what I do know, I'm no expert, and my knowledge is still extremely limited compared to those who, say, actually deal with processors as a direct part of their job... As such, it'd be cool to see some further insight on processor performance variables/metrics by an actual in-depth specialist of the sort.

For most tasks, the following are suitable improvements:
1. Higher clockspeed is ideal
2. Higher core count is ideal
3. More ram is idea
4. Higher ipc is nice. Just do game benchmark limiting down two chips to the same clock and cores, the higher performing one has better ipc (instruction per clock - cause not all CPU's are made equally thus there are multiple way a cpu can execute a task using logic gates. The improvement in pipeline along generation means we have been seeing quite the improvement in Ipc - of course here Ipc would matter per workload but avx algorithm uses every part of the cpu so any improvement will make a difference in you're use case. . .)
5. High speed storage for all that data - higher the better in demanding workloads such as editing. Put two 970 pro in raid 0, or if redundancy is needed then use one of the pcie slots for an added nvme card for 4 nvme drives in raid 10.
6. Cuda accelerated tasks is gud - better gpu power the better - does have diminishing returns where the more you increase performance wise the render time will still be the same due to cpu bottleneck - could use amd cards but dunno if you're render engine supports stream processors (amd's name to cuda cores I think**)
7. Better cooling, water cooling?? Or beefy air cooling setups. Noctua fans are always nice,
8. Gud Mobo - quality Mobo means better voltage regulation modules (vrm) thus clean power to the cpu.

And that's about it

You may want to look into "field-programmable gate array" this is basically hardware that can be programmed to perform a very specialized task. Like rendering video with a certain codec. Yet it can be re-programmed to any other kind of task at any time. The advantage of it is that a custom logical circuit can be programmed and executed as if it was specialized hardware for a special task, instead of using the generalized CPU. GPU (Graphics Processing Unit) is one such form of custom hardware that a "field-programmable gate array" could be programmed to emulate. GPU's are great for graphics because they have thousands of processors which run in parallel and all run the same command on different pieces of the data at the same time.

The real trick is getting software to use the available hardware effectively. If this even occurs, this is where most of the cost of software development can occur, because it's not easy and very time consuming.

Core count matters... At least if you use efficient Codecs and Encoders like x264 / x265 that offers a LOT better Rendertime-Quality-Size Ratio than all the built in Encoders you find in NLE`s (except TmpgEnc). If you feed your Premiere footage into a Bitrate based encoding workflow, you will need a lot more time because of 2 Pass encoding, otherwise you will end up with artifacts.
If you encode with a Constant Rate Factor (CRF) or a Constant Quantizer (CQ) (CQ is actually mathematically the best method to encode), you will be able to speed up your encoding a lot BUT here are more cores always better. Especially for x265 you can use the advantage of a high Core Count machine (even Dual socket or more because of NUMA Pools). It is also CPU Pool`s aware on Windows, wich means you can use more than only 64 Threads on each task (only physically limited by your CPU).


I can Encode a 10 Minute long 3800x2100p24 Footage on my Dual Socket Xeon E5-2696v3 (36Cores/72Threads) with a CRF of 23 and a Preset of "Slow" (with some extras like PME,WPP,PMODE and 6 B-Frames) at around 8 FPS that will took ~30 Minutes to complete with x265 Encoder (10bit). But on this machine i us only 1 Socket, meaning 18 Cores or 36 Threads, while on my second CPU socket i encode another Video at the same time. And ofc the Quality will be even better than on a long 2 Pass Bitrate based Encode.

Instead you'll be going for the best value you can find, the best cost to performance ratio, and then building a farm out of it. What they sold you is NOT SCALABLE. A farm is, a farm always is. So you'll be spending a lot on fast storage and fast networking, more than you'll be spending on those CPUs.

Or you could've saved yourself the trouble and expense, and just hired a remote rendering farm. Get yourself the fattest pipe you can get to the internet, then pay just for all the cheap burst instances you can on Google Cloud, It all depends on how fast you want it. Need it yesterday? Sure, get 10 nodes, get 100 nodes. Get all the nodes you want, you just pay by the minute, and you shut them down when you're done.

Or, if you want to avoid the hassle, just hire a cloud rendering service and they'll give you a plug and play solution, and you just pay for the ghz-hour.

Spending money on a single faster machine is the worst possible solution to your rendering issues.

It's funny the way you describe it because I had to explain this to a bunch of suits back in the day that buying more up to date hardware wouldn't mean their applications would run any faster.

I did some work for a big investment bank in Japan back in the day. The issue was they were running old hardware, Windows NT 4.0 still into the 2000's and needed to upgrade. So a lot of new servers were ordered, they wanted Windows 2000 put on them and that was my job. Problem was they weren't running any faster even with an extra processor in each server and loads more memory.

I explained that the software they were using and the launching of everything using batch files wasn't working because you might have two processors but the application is still designed for one. They needed to change their entire business model and actually buy new apps that were up to date and leverage Active Directory to get things done. It took some time but they finally got it.

2:48 Linus Tech Tips has gone really down hill.

I've worked for computer builders for about 20 years, and a lot of the time we would have to really scramble to get the customer the computer they needed, which often wasn't what they thought they wanted. However not having the resources to do massive amounts of speculative benchmarking there was a lot of guessing and googling involved. A lot of our customers also had their own homegrown software they needed to run, and finding out just how that software worked was often a nightmare.


Imagine a company needing a machine to run simulations of radio antenna, and the software used was developed in house. You have to find out how well it takes to being parallelized in the current version, and how hard it would be for them to rewrite for increased parallelization. Can the workload even be distributed to a cluster, or could it be rewritten to run on a GPU or even a GPU cluster? How much memory does it need, and how bandwidth intensive is it. Is the storage bandwidth and latency critical or would it be happy running of a tape drive from 1980?
In the end we managed to cut their simulation time radically. The test simulation took something like 11 hours on their old beast of a machine, but only about 20 - 30 minutes on the new machine, and it wasn't even that exotic.


One thing I never would allow was a machine throttling. We did a lot of testing to find out what kind of loads would stress the components the most. Components like the CPU, memory and the GPU was stressed both individually with targeted loads and in parallel to make sure the machine wouldn't overheat. Every machine also had to survive 24 hours in 40°C under full load without throttling before I would sign off on it.


Things like that kept companies coming back for their next machine or machines, but it also meant our computers tended to cost a fair bit more than the competition.

Destin, please put an insulator under your PC chassis (a piece of wood, cardboard, rubber mat, etc.). Also an important note on rendering after the explanation of my previous request..

Explanation : It looks like your chassis has a bottom mount power supply (and probably has an air intake on the bottom), if so... you don't want it pulling dust and carpet fibers into the power supply. Also ... in the past I have seen several computers develop erratic behavior which was a massive pain to troubleshoot. They appeared to have weird power issues, after a LOT of time and replacing components to test them (and out of desperation) I developed my own hair-brained theory. With it sitting on carpet, the nearby foot traffic and scrubbing on the carpet was inducing static electricity into the chassis. I have no idea if this was physically correct BUT after placing the chassis on an insulator the problems went away. I have lost count of how many times I "fixed" someone's computer by getting it off the carpet. In a video editing machine, an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.

Food for thought on the subject of video encoding: Have you considered building a local (in-home with what you have available) render farm or community render farm with any of your subscribers who also own After Effects and Media Encoder CC?

Hopefully Media Encoder CC will soon support full use of multiple GPUs (they may in the current version but if so I'm unaware that's fully implemented and supported) but until they do....the network rendering route may be a viable solution (or at the very least, you may be able to use your old machine with your new one on your local network.) to give you an extra performance boost.

I use multiple PC's with multiple GPU's to render scenes cooperatively on my local network with Blender (which I'm still horrible with but perpetually learning to use). The performance increase with mutli-PC network rendering was about 48% (almost cut my render times in half. I know it's apples and oranges but Media Encoder CC should still be able to see significant performance increases as well). I can't speak to the performance increase of network rendering of ME CC but if you have an extra computer on the network or other owners of the software willing to cooperate, it's at least worth looking into...especially if it saves you more time and potentially allows you to push your video quality a bit farther.

There's one thing missing here Destin, and it's a biggy, and it's in the first minute of the video.
( I'll explain in a way for everyone to follow ;) )
You're shooting on a camera that records a highly compressed video sequence using a CoDec that was designed for Content Delivery, not Content Creation CoDec.
Here's a test to try.
Scroll backwards through the timeline on your original PC, you'll probably see the scrolling be smooth, then jump, smooth, then jump.
Each jump is where the NLE is looking backwards through the vision for the previous keyframe at the start of one of the previous Long-G.O.P. segments.
Grab a mates Shogun or Video Assist or Odyessy recorder, set to ProRes or DNxHD, and when you go to scroll through the footage on the timeline, it'll respond faster, at every resolution.

CoDec's designed for content creation are assembled without the Group of Pictures compression of delivery CoDecs, so the CPU and GPU are not being hogged by the math needed to play them back, in the way h.264 and h.265 does.

Everything else you mention about choosing hardware, is what I went through when CS4 was new, grabbing a good CPU, good GPU, good, but not great parts, stuff that was affordable when X58 M/boards were new.
I still use that system to edit on in Resolve and render artwork using Daz Studio and the nVidia Iray render engine.
The timeline still scrolls fast, and HD export is nearly real-time with three nodes of colour correction in Resolve for any track.
4K, slows a bit, but that's what afternoon coffee and a good mattress at night is for :)

But agree 100% as to look for a best-use case scenario for the games or programs you're trying to run!  For example, while I did want a lot of cores, I saw that (generally) the 7980XE for $2K non-binned, wasn't quite as single thread oriented as a 7940X.  Some programs I have utilize a mix of both single and multi core capability so I needed a good performer in both aspects.  OC'd this 7940X to 4.5 stable, even though some lucky people have gotten 7980XEs to be faster.

Please, do note that the 8-core example was specific for that piece of software. I know they tried to explain it, but I know people are going to tell me for years after seeing this video that lower spec processors are actually better.

Software that can handle more cores will of course benefit more from the 12-core version. Likewise if you're not only using that one piece of software. Most people who need a workstation would not need it to run just a single piece of software, but sometimes up to 15-20 softwares simultaneously. With the right core management, the more cores the better.

I have been building my own computers from scratch since I first built a PC compatible in the '90s (before that I owned a C64 and various Amigas). It's THE best way to do it, not only do you get exactly what you want, but you can do it much cheaper if you select all the parts yourself. Also, you will get to know your computer much better and with a little research, you can even fix it when it has problems. I have always fixed my own, and all my friends sadly (don't tell anyone you know what you're doing!)

I plan on doing a new upgrade after 8 years as computer parts have FINALLY come down in price, no thanks to all the bitcoin farmers. I plan to do more 3D rendering with Blender (free 3D software, check it out) which will use all of the cores in your CPU as well as all the processing power of your GPU, one or the other in v2.79, BOTH in the newer 2.80 when it is released.

Oh, and to answer the question as to why an 8 core CPU is faster than a 12 core, well, I noticed the 12 core was an AMD that didn't have hyperthreading. The 8 core CPU was an INTEL which has hyperthreading. The difference is t hat with the AMD 12 core CPU, each CPU can do one task at a time, or a single thread. The Intel's hyperthreading can do 2 threads (or "tasks") at a time, so that 8 core Intel with hyperthreading is like having a 16 core CPU, which should give you a clue as to why it is faster than t he AMD.

Now newer AMD CPUs will have hyperthreading, and AMDs tend to be cheaper, so keep an eye out for that. The main thing you want to look for is how many threads can each core handle, then do the math.

Also, graphic cards have come a long way as well and can do amazing computing (it's why bitcoin farmers were buying them up which drove their price up). Even with all those cores in a CPU, when given a choice, you want to go with a good GPU (graphic processor or graphic card) instead as it can do MUCH better, at least when it comes to 3D rendering. Blender is kewl as it will literally show you, on screen what each core is rendering with a tiny box. But CPUs can only handle a small amount of data, a graphic card's GPU can handle a massive amount all at once.

Of course, for a gaming system, multicore CPUs don't really improve things, you want a good graphic card and lets not forget memory. The more memory in the fewer number of memory chips the better. If you want 16G of RAM, i recommend two 8G chips instead of four 4G chips for speed.

Also, a faster hard drive, like a solid state drive (SSD) can be good for specific tasks. Some people buy a smaller SSD just for the operating system and a larger HDD for everything else, it equals a faster bootup time. For video editing it might be a little faster to have a dedicated SSD just for your videos for faster loads and saves.

Don't cheap out on case fans either. Organize your cables inside your case to promote good airflow and you will keep your components happier and cooler.

Computers prior to 2005 were also purpose built. SGI workstations for graphics design, Sun processors for servers, embedded or other devices (think your Nintendo or Sega or Playstation systems). And love that the engineer doesn't really know Moore's law. It has nothing to do with computing speed and everything to do with cost. Namely that the amount of transistors that could be crammed into a given area doubled about every 18 months (used to be every year, but that was back in the 60s). That hasn't changed. More cores isn't because Moore's law doesn't work anymore. It is because that is easier to deal with than trying to keep ramping up the linear speed of the core. So, single-threaded problems don't get much faster, but others do.

The problem with more cores is two. Normally they have a lower clock speed to keep power within a certain tdp and software support. The software has to support multiple cores. Some do and some do not.

In the case of not supporting a lot of cores, less cores running faster typically will rule the day. The i9 9900k has a base clock but will turbo boost to certain speeds depending on core use, same with AMD processors. However Intel does have a clock speed advantage. By that I mean Intels CPUs can clock higher. On that CPU all cores being maxed out will run at 4.7ghz while 4 would be 4.8ghz and 2 run at 5ghz. The Ryzen 1920x, a 12 core CPU, on the other hand can only run all cores at 3.7ghz. That's a 1ghz drop from the i9 and it makes a difference.

As well some software can utilize GPUs for rendering which is vastly faster.

For multiple cores the best area is typically servers as they are normally relegated to VM systems where you assign cores to do certain VMs. For example you have a single 24 core server and you split it into 6 4 core VM systems so each VM uses 4 cores to run and as well split the memory and disk space ect.

They are right that it does depend on the task you are doing but also budget. Not everyone can afford even the i9 9900k so there is a balance to building a system. However Puget is probably one of the best custom builders out there. Nice clean well built designs.

Ok. I have a few issues with the selection of CPU they went with here. According to Puget's own testing of core performance in Adobe Premiere, 1080p rendering doesn't utilize more than about 8 cores (even for very complex timelines), and 4k rendering doesn't utilize more than 10 cores (actual parallelization above 8 cores in any encoding scenario in Premiere is abysmal, and generally not worth it). So, in summary, Premiere is not very efficient above 6 cores, and it drops off to nearly nothing in pretty much all cases about 10 cores. ...And they spec'd an i9-7980XE 18 core cpu, with a single thread PassMark of 2342. This chip is about $2000 USD, and literally 1/2 of the cores will NOT be effectively used by Premiere. The i9-9900K is $1000, single thread rating of 2906, and 8 cores. Premiere will definitely be able to take maximum advantage of those cores, and each core is 24% faster than the chip that costs twice as much. The 9900k uses about 1/2 the electricity and produces about 1/2 the heat, so you save money in multiple ways short term and long term. How about sum $1000 for the non-baller renderers out there? For $480, you can get the i7-8086K with 6 cores, and single thread of 2846, or for $410 you can get an i7-9700k, 8 cores single thread rating 2788. Their per thread performance is within 3%, and the extra two cores will only be utilized in very complex timelines and 4k (1080p won't really see much difference about 5-6 cores, ever). SO... It's kind of a toss-up on these two.
There are more than 30 CPUs on the PassMark site listing better per-thread performance than the one Puget speced on this computer, and pretty much every single one of them cost FAR less. So, if you are going to build your own computer, and don't want to throw away your money, NEVER just blindly follow a build guide somebody made. For that more than $1000 price difference in CPU cost alone, you can get a better SSD, or a better video card, or make an extra mortgage payment on your house and save hundreds of extra dollars in interest on your loan.

I went from a 4 core Xeon to a 6 core I7 (with hyperthreading).  Also got a nice video card (GTX 580).  I ran rendering tests.  First the old machine.  10 hours. Unfortunately not all the drivers for all the formats support a GPU.  I didn't have a problem with letting the computer do its thing all night.  The problem was when I messed up with some edit and had to re-render.  Then it is another day before I was done.

If it is about production, and editing multiple videos at a time, you have to ask yourself if it is more efficient to get 1 faster system, or invest in a 2nd system, so one can 'cook' while the other is actively being used to edit. Or with Adobe's software you set it up to off-load rendering jobs and invest in a small server to send render jobs to while you edit your next project on your main rig.

Also, while Puget's bench-marking is good, like all bench-marking it is only for a single use case. For example; why does Adobe run faster on a smaller CPU? Because it does not take advantage of the extra cores of a high end processor and the fewer cores you have, the easier it is to overclock it. BUT, what are you giving up by going with the smaller chip? While the system is rendering you could use extra cores to import your next job. You could trans-code other projects. Just because YOU can't work on more than one thing at once does not mean your computer cant. And is Adobe's core limit something set in stone? They could drop an update one day and utilize more cores and then you loose capability on multi-tasking AND rendering time.

Another thing that Puget does that really bothers me, is that they essentially sell overpriced game rigs, slap in a quatro, and call it a professional workstation, when that is really not true. Will it run faster than, lets say, a xeon based workstation from a major brand like Dell or HP? Yes. But at the same time, almost anyone can build a similar product themselves for a small fraction of the cost. But a true workstation is more about reliability and service of a system than simply having something fast. A workstation is going to have hardware redundancy to prevent data loss with at least a RAID array and ECC memory (if not dual PSUs). And workstation class support means that when you have a problem, someone comes to your place of business and fixes is within 24 or 48 hours rather than you packing up your glorified game rig and sending it away for a few days.

Anywho; for people watching this video, and wanting a similarly capable rig I would suggest either going with a local botique shop (because botiques like Puget are not bad if you can get local support), or going with a major brand like Dell, HP, or (*shivers*) Apple.

This makes me sort of upset, because about ~12 years ago, I had the idea to do this exact same thing, locally, and ended up asking people what they thought about the idea. The idea being to create custom-tailored computers according to a person's (or a business's) specific workload - essentially abstracting away their worry of what components to get etc. My plan was to ask simple questions like what software are you intending to use, what are you doing with it, what is your budget - and the job of my company would be to come up with the optimal combination for each specific customer.

Now, the reason this makes me upset, is because at the time - my idea was laughed off as stupid, by essentially everyone I asked. "Why would anyone do that, building a computer is so easy, also you'll never get businesses to buy from you, they'll always stick to off-the-shelf PC's like Dell". I was younger at the time and less confident in my ideas, so I was extremely disappointed in the response I got while pitching the idea...

It's pretty clear at this point that I had a good idea. And I had a well-thought-out idea too, I had tons of documentation for procedures and how to handle things, that I just ditched, due to feeling so disappointed and discouraged back then.
Perhaps filming and editing at 30 or 24fps would be much more beneficial also on us end users…

This is basics really. Don't ever buy a pre-assembled computer. Always buy parts and assemble them together yourself.
Even a complete newbie can do the necessary research to accomplish this task. You don't need an "expert" for that.
Sure, they have the benchmarks to back up their reasoning and that's great. But that's also all they have.

And how did we ever get to the point where hardware need to be selected based on what software there is? It's always been about getting the right software for the job.
Software is easily shaped to fit hardware. Got 8 cores? Cool, let's just run 8 threads. Oh, you got 12 cores? Let's spawn 12 threads! EASY!

I get it that multithreading isn't as simple as that. But that's a problem for the software department, not the end user. If your application can't do proper multithreading then you find one that does.
The computer has no issues with it. The tasks themselves are well suited to multithreading (image manipulation and assembling) and even compression can be put in a multithreaded environment.

Also, your camera isn't outpacing your computer... Your camera just doesn't do that much processing!
If you render in the exact same format that your camera records at you will find that your computer can run that real time. At the expense of much longer upload times and youtube processing times. Because youtube WILL compress your uploaded work either way. So why bother?
Either way, it's the encoding that takes time.

If you want to speed it up a little bit more follow the 4 major things. #1: enough memory for what you are doing. I constantly use 32gb+ editing 4K, get the amount you need for YOUR workflow. #2: Dont edit directly from a external, put it on a drive by itself. I have a dedicated 480GB SSD for a project. Once done I archive the whole project (easy 1 step in premiere) onto a external backup for long term storage. #3: Use a different drive that is NOT the OS or project file drive for the "strach disk". I have another 480GB SSD for that. #4: Render out to a different drive that isnt your project files. Temp / Strach disk SSD is okay since the final render doesnt use the temp data by default.

You will be surpised those simple steps can cut hours off a render. Encoding to your project / os drive and without enough system memory is baffling to me, but im always seeing this everytime I work on someones editor and they wonder why its so slow.

I'm a computer/tech enthusiast and I can tell you that Puget Systems are well known in the tech community, they are often recommended to people who are scared to do something wrong when they choose the parts and build their pc, or for people who don't have the time to look at all the benchmarks to find what's better for their use case.
However, they're never really recommended to people who are curious and enjoy researching and reading benchmarks. That's because what Puget systems do, isn't out of your reach if like i said you're interesting in learning all that yourself. Choosing the best combination of parts for your use case doesn't get much more complicated than knowing whether you're going to do gaming or streaming or rendering and look up a few benchmarks of cpus and gpus.


I won't go in too much detail because just as they say in the video, every combination of computer parts has a specific task at which it's best, and knowing every combination and what each one is best at, isn't the most worthwhile thing to do, unless you're a tech enthusiast like me and you actually enjoy knowing all that.


Examples:
If you really want to push it though, it can get very complex. For eg you can make your pc optimized for specific games/rendering programs. If you like to play an older game, you're going to prefer to have a cpu that's said to have a high single thread performance (or single core perf), because older games weren't coded to leverage several cores or even know about the existence of more than 1 core. More recent games however are capable of leveraging 4 6 or 8 cores, with multithreading, so you're going to be able to buy a high core-count cpu that's going to be really good for your specific games as well as stream or rendering, which is really good if you want one single pc that can do everything really well.
Then there's the graphics card and the bottlenecks between the gpu and the cpu, where you have to know if you're not buying an overkill processor compared to your graphics card, or vice versa. Buying a 1200€ gpu and pair it with a 350€ cpu is nonsense, UNLESS you're going to do Adobe premiere rendering, because that program uses the graphics card to render, not the processor.
And then, scientific use case.. This one is more complicated, because you have to also factor in the operating system, windows vs linux. That's because when you do scientific research, you use many many programs, and they're ALL extremely optimized for what they do (unless 99% of regular consumer programs). So one program might be able to leverage 16, 32, or even 64 cores, with hyperthreading, so 32 64 or 128(256) threads. But, windows sucks at using more than 8 cores, because of the infamous scheduler, whereas linux doesn't have that problem.


So you can see depending on how specific what you do is, and how good you want your pc to be at it, things can get really complex. And that's mostly where Puget Systems comes in and finds its place. If you want a beast of a gaming pc, even if you really know nothing whatsoever about pc tech, it takes a 5min google search to find all the gaming-oriented components and then you choose based on your budget.

Because it was basically just an advertisement for Puget Systems in exchange for them building him a PC. He tried to hide the fact by putting 30 seconds of "how computers work 101" in there but it was a badly veiled attempt.

While his is not a tech/computer channel it would have been a much better fit for his type of channel, and his general audience, to make a video on how you actually determine what parts would be needed for an editing workstation, narrowing down the options with price/performance metrics, and how to actually assemble a computer. It could have actually been an informational topic on entry level computing for his non tech-inclined audience. Any idiot with half a brain can figure out how to put together a computer (especially with all the resources and videos available online) with just a couple days of research and shopping around, but most people are either too lazy to try to do it themselves, scared off of the prospect by not knowing where to start, or just want that quick easy buy-a-box and it werks* solution. That's why you have so many people who just buy whatever Dell or HP display model is being shown at Best Buy or Office Max, and why system builders like Puget, Alienware, IBuyPower, or OriginPC exist at all.

So this is to any of you out there, who may be in the market for a new PC and are thinking about buying a new computer. Don't. Don't do it. Spend a little time to figure out what you need, and how to put it together. Then buy all the parts and put it together yourself. Your'e not only going to save yourself a couple hundred bucks but it will also give you a more customized fit for exactly what you need out of your computer.

I think this video is a little dangerous. You dont need to go through a company like Peugeot to do this sort of thing. If you need a system, do some self research. Some programs value core count (more cores) others value clock speed (speed of a single core). The forums of whatever software you use will certainly have this information. Also do research about what your software values, CPU power or graphics card power. This will tell you if you need a high power GPU or if you can scale back to save cost. After that, find the parts that match what you need within the price range you want to spend (if you have a lot of money, buy top of the line, if you need value then buy a few generations back in the same lines) Then pull up a video of how to assemble a computer (by anyone other than the Verge...my god they botched that)

This is all something that any person can do. Peugeot and other companies like them fill a void where people dont have the time to do the research. But if you cant afford the premium they charge, dont get scared off.

As I've suffered from long rendering time before, the issue is not waiting for the video to render it is how to organize the day especially if the editor has other professional commitments.

If rendering time takes 10 hours, then the editor will need to finish all editing and start the rendering process by 9 pm in order to have the video ready at the start of the next day and as early in the morning as possible (especially if you're meeting a client or have a youtube upload schedule to meet).

To do so, the editor will have to spend the late afternoon and all the evening doing editing work to start the rendering process ASAP. Therefore missing having dinner with family or having a social life in the evening.

If the rendering process takes only 2 to 3 hours, then the editor doesn't need to schedule rendering during bedtime, it can be scheduled during gym time, family time, or even shopping time which would give the editor more freedom in making his/her daily schedule.

Selecting hardware goes beyond the application specific, it's task specific. Many applications will be a mix between what can be parralellised and what needs raw frequency on a few cores or leverages specific circuits in a CPU. So it's very much a case of what task you need to be most efficient and you'll often find that you're making a trade off either way.

Sometimes you need to consider the software you are using for the tasks you do, some of the more popular software is rooted from low core count era's and sometimes when upgrading the hardware you're best served considering both hardware and software.
